trans-unit.source: Learn More: Azure AD Password Management | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Learn More: Azure AD Password Management | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Advanced topics on Azure AD Password Management, including how password writeback works, password writeback security, how the password reset portal works, and what data is used by password reset.
trans-unit.target: Advanced topics on Azure AD Password Management, including how password writeback works, password writeback security, how the password reset portal works, and what data is used by password reset.

trans-unit.source: Learn more about Password Management
trans-unit.target: Learn more about Password Management

trans-unit.source: If you have already deployed Password Management, or are just looking to learn more about the technical nitty gritty of how it works before deploying, this section will give you a good overview of the technical concepts behind the service.
trans-unit.target: If you have already deployed Password Management, or are just looking to learn more about the technical nitty gritty of how it works before deploying, this section will give you a good overview of the technical concepts behind the service.

trans-unit.source: We'll cover the following:
trans-unit.target: We'll cover the following:

trans-unit.source: Password writeback overview
trans-unit.target: Password writeback overview

trans-unit.source: How pasword writeback works
trans-unit.target: How pasword writeback works

trans-unit.source: Scenarios supported for password writeback
trans-unit.target: Scenarios supported for password writeback

trans-unit.source: Password writeback security model
trans-unit.target: Password writeback security model

trans-unit.target: How does the password reset portal work?

trans-unit.target: What data is used by password reset?

trans-unit.source: Password writeback overview
trans-unit.target: Password writeback overview

trans-unit.source: Password writeback is an [Azure Active Directory Connect](active-directory-aadconnect) component that can be enabled and used by the current subscribers of Azure Active Directory Premium.
trans-unit.target: Password writeback is an [Azure Active Directory Connect](active-directory-aadconnect) component that can be enabled and used by the current subscribers of Azure Active Directory Premium.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure Active Directory Editions](active-directory-editions.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure Active Directory Editions](active-directory-editions.md).

trans-unit.source: Password writeback allows you to configure your cloud tenant to write passwords back to you on-premises Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Password writeback allows you to configure your cloud tenant to write passwords back to you on-premises Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: It obviates you from having to set up and manage a complicated on-premises self-service password reset solution, and it provides a convenient cloud-based way for your users to reset their on-premises passwords wherever they are.
trans-unit.target: It obviates you from having to set up and manage a complicated on-premises self-service password reset solution, and it provides a convenient cloud-based way for your users to reset their on-premises passwords wherever they are.

trans-unit.source: Read on for some of the key features of password writeback:
trans-unit.target: Read on for some of the key features of password writeback:

trans-unit.source: Zero delay feedback.
trans-unit.target: Zero delay feedback.

trans-unit.source: Password writeback is a synchronous operation.
trans-unit.target: Password writeback is a synchronous operation.

trans-unit.source: Your users will be notified immediately if their password did not meet policy or was not able to be reset or changed for any reason.
trans-unit.target: Your users will be notified immediately if their password did not meet policy or was not able to be reset or changed for any reason.

trans-unit.source: Supports resetting passwords for users using AD FS or other federation technologies.
trans-unit.target: Supports resetting passwords for users using AD FS or other federation technologies.

trans-unit.source: With password writeback, as long as the federated user accounts are synchronized into your Azure AD tenant, they will be able to manage their on-premises AD passwords from the cloud.
trans-unit.target: With password writeback, as long as the federated user accounts are synchronized into your Azure AD tenant, they will be able to manage their on-premises AD passwords from the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Supports resetting passwords for users using password hash sync.
trans-unit.target: Supports resetting passwords for users using password hash sync.

trans-unit.source: When the password reset service detects that a synchronized user account is enabled for password hash sync, we reset both this account’s on-premises and cloud password simultaneously.
trans-unit.target: When the password reset service detects that a synchronized user account is enabled for password hash sync, we reset both this account’s on-premises and cloud password simultaneously.

trans-unit.source: Supports changing passwords from the access panel and Office 365.
trans-unit.target: Supports changing passwords from the access panel and Office 365.

trans-unit.source: When federated or password sync’d users come to change their expired or non-expired passwords, we’ll write those passwords back to your local AD environment.
trans-unit.target: When federated or password sync’d users come to change their expired or non-expired passwords, we’ll write those passwords back to your local AD environment.

trans-unit.source: **Supports writing back passwords when an admin reset them from the** [**Azure Management Portal**](https://manage.windowsazure.com).
trans-unit.target: **Supports writing back passwords when an admin reset them from the** [**Azure Management Portal**](https://manage.windowsazure.com).

trans-unit.source: Whenever an admin resets a user’s password in the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com), if that user is federated or password sync’d, we’ll set the password the admin selects on your local AD, as well.
trans-unit.target: Whenever an admin resets a user’s password in the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com), if that user is federated or password sync’d, we’ll set the password the admin selects on your local AD, as well.

trans-unit.source: This is currently not supported in the Office Admin Portal.
trans-unit.target: This is currently not supported in the Office Admin Portal.

trans-unit.source: Enforces your on-premises AD password policies.
trans-unit.target: Enforces your on-premises AD password policies.

trans-unit.source: When a user resets his/her password, we make sure that it meets your on-premises AD policy before committing it to that directory.
trans-unit.target: When a user resets his/her password, we make sure that it meets your on-premises AD policy before committing it to that directory.

trans-unit.source: This includes history, complexity, age, password filters, and any other password restrictions you have defined in your local AD.
trans-unit.target: This includes history, complexity, age, password filters, and any other password restrictions you have defined in your local AD.

trans-unit.source: Doesn’t require any inbound firewall rules.
trans-unit.target: Doesn’t require any inbound firewall rules.

trans-unit.source: Password writeback uses an Azure Service Bus relay as an underlying communication channel, meaning that you do not have to open any inbound ports on your firewall for this feature to work.
trans-unit.target: Password writeback uses an Azure Service Bus relay as an underlying communication channel, meaning that you do not have to open any inbound ports on your firewall for this feature to work.

trans-unit.source: Is not supported for user accounts that exist within protected groups in your on-premises Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Is not supported for user accounts that exist within protected groups in your on-premises Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: For more information about protected groups, see [Protected Accounts and Groups in Active Directory](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/dn535499.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about protected groups, see [Protected Accounts and Groups in Active Directory](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/dn535499.aspx).

trans-unit.source: How password writeback works
trans-unit.target: How password writeback works

trans-unit.source: Password writeback has three main components:
trans-unit.target: Password writeback has three main components:

trans-unit.source: Password Reset cloud service (this is also integrated into Azure AD’s password change pages)
trans-unit.target: Password Reset cloud service (this is also integrated into Azure AD’s password change pages)

trans-unit.source: Tenant-specific Azure Service Bus relay
trans-unit.target: Tenant-specific Azure Service Bus relay

trans-unit.source: On-prem password reset endpoint
trans-unit.target: On-prem password reset endpoint

trans-unit.source: They fit together as described in the below diagram:
trans-unit.target: They fit together as described in the below diagram:

trans-unit.source: When a federated or password hash sync’d user comes to reset or change his or her password in the cloud, the following occurs:
trans-unit.target: When a federated or password hash sync’d user comes to reset or change his or her password in the cloud, the following occurs:

trans-unit.source: We check to see what type of password the user has.
trans-unit.target: We check to see what type of password the user has.

trans-unit.source: If we see the password is managed on premises, then we ensure the writeback service is up and running.
trans-unit.target: If we see the password is managed on premises, then we ensure the writeback service is up and running.

trans-unit.source: If it is, we let the user proceed, if it is not, we tell the user that their password cannot be reset here.
trans-unit.target: If it is, we let the user proceed, if it is not, we tell the user that their password cannot be reset here.

trans-unit.source: Next, the user passes the appropriate authentication gates and reaches the reset password screen.
trans-unit.target: Next, the user passes the appropriate authentication gates and reaches the reset password screen.

trans-unit.source: The user selects a new password and confirms it.
trans-unit.target: The user selects a new password and confirms it.

trans-unit.source: Upon clicking submit, we encrypt the plaintext password with a symmetric key that was created during the writeback setup process.
trans-unit.target: Upon clicking submit, we encrypt the plaintext password with a symmetric key that was created during the writeback setup process.

trans-unit.source: After encrypting the password, we include it in a payload that gets sent over an HTTPS channel to your tenant specific service bus relay (that we also set up for you during the writeback setup process).
trans-unit.target: After encrypting the password, we include it in a payload that gets sent over an HTTPS channel to your tenant specific service bus relay (that we also set up for you during the writeback setup process).

trans-unit.source: This relay is protected by a randomly generated password that only your on-premises installation knows.
trans-unit.target: This relay is protected by a randomly generated password that only your on-premises installation knows.

trans-unit.source: Once the message reaches service bus, the password reset endpoint automatically wakes up and sees that it has a reset request pending.
trans-unit.target: Once the message reaches service bus, the password reset endpoint automatically wakes up and sees that it has a reset request pending.

trans-unit.source: The service then looks for the user in question by using the cloud anchor attribute.
trans-unit.target: The service then looks for the user in question by using the cloud anchor attribute.

trans-unit.source: For this lookup to succeed, the user object must exist in the AD connector space, it must be linked to the corresponding MV object, and it must be linked to the corresponding AAD connector object.
trans-unit.target: For this lookup to succeed, the user object must exist in the AD connector space, it must be linked to the corresponding MV object, and it must be linked to the corresponding AAD connector object.

trans-unit.source: Finally, in order for sync to find this user account, the link from AD connector object to MV must have the sync rule `Microsoft.InfromADUserAccountEnabled.xxx` on the link.
trans-unit.target: Finally, in order for sync to find this user account, the link from AD connector object to MV must have the sync rule `Microsoft.InfromADUserAccountEnabled.xxx` on the link.

trans-unit.source: This is needed because when the call comes in from the cloud, the sync engine uses the cloudAnchor attribute to look up the AAD connector space object, then follows the link back to the MV object, and then follows the link back to the AD object.
trans-unit.target: This is needed because when the call comes in from the cloud, the sync engine uses the cloudAnchor attribute to look up the AAD connector space object, then follows the link back to the MV object, and then follows the link back to the AD object.

trans-unit.source: Because there could be multiple AD objects (multi-forest) for the same user, the sync engine relies on the `Microsoft.InfromADUserAccountEnabled.xxx` link to pick the correct one.
trans-unit.target: Because there could be multiple AD objects (multi-forest) for the same user, the sync engine relies on the `Microsoft.InfromADUserAccountEnabled.xxx` link to pick the correct one.

trans-unit.source: Once the user account is found, we attempt to reset the password directly in the appropriate AD forest.
trans-unit.target: Once the user account is found, we attempt to reset the password directly in the appropriate AD forest.

trans-unit.source: If the password set operation is successful, we tell the user their password has been modified and that they can go on their merry way.
trans-unit.target: If the password set operation is successful, we tell the user their password has been modified and that they can go on their merry way.

trans-unit.source: If the password set operation fails, we return the error to the user and let them try again.
trans-unit.target: If the password set operation fails, we return the error to the user and let them try again.

trans-unit.source: The operation might fail because the service was down, because the password they selected did not meet organization policies, because we could not find the user in the local AD, or any number of reasons.
trans-unit.target: The operation might fail because the service was down, because the password they selected did not meet organization policies, because we could not find the user in the local AD, or any number of reasons.

trans-unit.source: We have a specific message for many of these cases and tell the user what they can do to resolve the issue.
trans-unit.target: We have a specific message for many of these cases and tell the user what they can do to resolve the issue.

trans-unit.source: Scenarios supported for password writeback
trans-unit.target: Scenarios supported for password writeback

trans-unit.source: The table below describes which scenarios are supported for which versions of our sync capabilities.
trans-unit.target: The table below describes which scenarios are supported for which versions of our sync capabilities.

trans-unit.source: In general, it is highly recommended that you install the latest version of [Azure AD Connect](active-directory-aadconnect.md#download-azure-ad-connect) if you want to use password writeback.
trans-unit.target: In general, it is highly recommended that you install the latest version of [Azure AD Connect](active-directory-aadconnect.md#download-azure-ad-connect) if you want to use password writeback.

trans-unit.source: Password writeback security model
trans-unit.target: Password writeback security model

trans-unit.source: Password writeback is a highly secure and robust service.
trans-unit.target: Password writeback is a highly secure and robust service.

trans-unit.source: In order to ensure your information is protected, we enable a 4-tiered security model that is described below.
trans-unit.target: In order to ensure your information is protected, we enable a 4-tiered security model that is described below.

trans-unit.source: **Tenant specific service-bus relay** – When you set up the service, we set up a tenant-specific service bus relay that is protected by a randomly generated strong password that Microsoft never has access to.
trans-unit.target: **Tenant specific service-bus relay** – When you set up the service, we set up a tenant-specific service bus relay that is protected by a randomly generated strong password that Microsoft never has access to.

trans-unit.source: **Locked down, cryptographically strong, password encryption key** – After the service bus relay is created, we create a strong symmetric key which we use to encrypt the password as it comes over the wire.
trans-unit.target: **Locked down, cryptographically strong, password encryption key** – After the service bus relay is created, we create a strong symmetric key which we use to encrypt the password as it comes over the wire.

trans-unit.source: This key lives only in your tenant's secret store in the cloud, which is heavily locked down and audited, just like any password in the directory.
trans-unit.target: This key lives only in your tenant's secret store in the cloud, which is heavily locked down and audited, just like any password in the directory.

trans-unit.source: **Industry standard TLS** – When a password reset or change operation occurs in the cloud, we take the plaintext password and encrypt it with your public key.
trans-unit.target: **Industry standard TLS** – When a password reset or change operation occurs in the cloud, we take the plaintext password and encrypt it with your public key.

trans-unit.source: We then plop that into an HTTPS message which is sent over an encrypted channel using Microsoft’s SSL certs to your service bus relay.
trans-unit.target: We then plop that into an HTTPS message which is sent over an encrypted channel using Microsoft’s SSL certs to your service bus relay.

trans-unit.source: After that message arrives into Service Bus, your on-prem agent wakes up, authenticates to Service Bus using the strong password that had been previously generated, picks up the encrypted message, decrypts it using the private key we generated, and then attempts to set the password through the AD DS SetPassword API.
trans-unit.target: After that message arrives into Service Bus, your on-prem agent wakes up, authenticates to Service Bus using the strong password that had been previously generated, picks up the encrypted message, decrypts it using the private key we generated, and then attempts to set the password through the AD DS SetPassword API.

trans-unit.source: This step is what allows us to enforce your AD on-prem password policy (complexity, age, history, filters, etc) in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: This step is what allows us to enforce your AD on-prem password policy (complexity, age, history, filters, etc) in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: **Message expiration policies** – Finally, if for some reason the message sits in Service Bus because your on-prem service is down, it will be timed out and removed after several minutes in order to increase security even further.
trans-unit.target: **Message expiration policies** – Finally, if for some reason the message sits in Service Bus because your on-prem service is down, it will be timed out and removed after several minutes in order to increase security even further.

trans-unit.source: How does the password reset portal work?
trans-unit.target: How does the password reset portal work?

trans-unit.source: When a user navigates to the password reset portal, a workflow is kicked off to determine if that user account is valid, what organization that users belongs to, where that user’s password is managed, and whether or not the user is licensed to use the feature.
trans-unit.target: When a user navigates to the password reset portal, a workflow is kicked off to determine if that user account is valid, what organization that users belongs to, where that user’s password is managed, and whether or not the user is licensed to use the feature.

trans-unit.source: Read through the steps below to learn about the logic behind the password reset page.
trans-unit.target: Read through the steps below to learn about the logic behind the password reset page.

trans-unit.source: User clicks on the Can’t access your account link or goes directly to [https://passwordreset.microsoftonline.com](https://passwordreset.microsoftonline.com).
trans-unit.target: User clicks on the Can’t access your account link or goes directly to [https://passwordreset.microsoftonline.com](https://passwordreset.microsoftonline.com).

trans-unit.source: User enters a user id and passes a captcha.
trans-unit.target: User enters a user id and passes a captcha.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD verifies if the user is able to use this feature by doing the following:
trans-unit.target: Azure AD verifies if the user is able to use this feature by doing the following:

trans-unit.source: Checks that the user has this feature enabled and an Azure AD license assigned.
trans-unit.target: Checks that the user has this feature enabled and an Azure AD license assigned.

trans-unit.source: If the user does not have this feature enabled or a license assigned, the user is asked to contact his or her administrator to reset his or her password.
trans-unit.target: If the user does not have this feature enabled or a license assigned, the user is asked to contact his or her administrator to reset his or her password.

trans-unit.source: Checks that the user has the right challenge data defined on his or her account in accordance with administrator policy.
trans-unit.target: Checks that the user has the right challenge data defined on his or her account in accordance with administrator policy.

trans-unit.source: If policy requires only one challenge, then it is ensured that the user has the appropriate data defined for at least one of the challenges enabled by the administrator policy.
trans-unit.target: If policy requires only one challenge, then it is ensured that the user has the appropriate data defined for at least one of the challenges enabled by the administrator policy.

trans-unit.source: If the user is not configured, then the user is advised to contact his or her administrator to reset his or her password.
trans-unit.target: If the user is not configured, then the user is advised to contact his or her administrator to reset his or her password.

trans-unit.source: If the policy requires two challenges, then it is ensured that the user has the appropriate data defined for at least two of the challenges enabled by the administrator policy.
trans-unit.target: If the policy requires two challenges, then it is ensured that the user has the appropriate data defined for at least two of the challenges enabled by the administrator policy.

trans-unit.source: If the user is not configured, then we the user is advised to contact his or her administrator to reset his or her password.
trans-unit.target: If the user is not configured, then we the user is advised to contact his or her administrator to reset his or her password.

trans-unit.source: Checks whether or not the user’s password is managed on premises (federated or password hash sync’d).
trans-unit.target: Checks whether or not the user’s password is managed on premises (federated or password hash sync’d).

trans-unit.source: If writeback is deployed and the user’s password is managed on premises, then the user is allowed to proceed to authenticate and reset his or her password.
trans-unit.target: If writeback is deployed and the user’s password is managed on premises, then the user is allowed to proceed to authenticate and reset his or her password.

trans-unit.source: If writeback is not deployed and the user’s password is managed on premises, then the user is asked to contact his or her administrator to reset his or her password.
trans-unit.target: If writeback is not deployed and the user’s password is managed on premises, then the user is asked to contact his or her administrator to reset his or her password.

trans-unit.source: If it is determined that the user is able to successfully reset his or her password, then the user is guided through the reset process.
trans-unit.target: If it is determined that the user is able to successfully reset his or her password, then the user is guided through the reset process.

trans-unit.source: Learn more about how to deploy password writeback at [Getting Started: Azure AD Password Management](active-directory-passwords-getting-started.md).
trans-unit.target: Learn more about how to deploy password writeback at [Getting Started: Azure AD Password Management](active-directory-passwords-getting-started.md).

trans-unit.source: What data is used by password reset?
trans-unit.target: What data is used by password reset?

trans-unit.source: The following table outlines where and how this data is used during password reset and is designed to help you decide which authentication options are appropriate for your organization.
trans-unit.target: The following table outlines where and how this data is used during password reset and is designed to help you decide which authentication options are appropriate for your organization.

trans-unit.source: This table also shows any formatting requirements for cases where you are providing data on behalf of users from input paths that do not validate this data.
trans-unit.target: This table also shows any formatting requirements for cases where you are providing data on behalf of users from input paths that do not validate this data.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Office Phone does not appear in the registration portal because users are currently not able to edit this property in the directory.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Office Phone does not appear in the registration portal because users are currently not able to edit this property in the directory.

trans-unit.source: Contact Method Name
trans-unit.target: Contact Method Name

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory Data Element
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory Data Element

trans-unit.source: Used / Settable Where?
trans-unit.target: Used / Settable Where?

trans-unit.source: Format requirements
trans-unit.target: Format requirements

trans-unit.source: Office Phone
trans-unit.target: Office Phone

trans-unit.source: PhoneNumber
trans-unit.target: PhoneNumber

trans-unit.source: e.g. Set-MsolUser -UserPrincipalName JWarner@contoso.com -PhoneNumber "+1 1234567890x1234"
trans-unit.target: e.g. Set-MsolUser -UserPrincipalName JWarner@contoso.com -PhoneNumber "+1 1234567890x1234"

trans-unit.source: Used in:
trans-unit.target: Used in:

trans-unit.source: Password Reset Portal
trans-unit.target: Password Reset Portal

trans-unit.source: Settable from:
trans-unit.target: Settable from:

trans-unit.source: PhoneNumber is settable from PowerShell, DirSync, Azure Management Portal, and the Office Admin Portal
trans-unit.target: PhoneNumber is settable from PowerShell, DirSync, Azure Management Portal, and the Office Admin Portal

trans-unit.source: +ccc xxxyyyzzzz (e.g. +1 1234567890)
trans-unit.target: +ccc xxxyyyzzzz (e.g. +1 1234567890)

trans-unit.source: Mobile Phone
trans-unit.target: Mobile Phone

trans-unit.source: AuthenticationPhone
trans-unit.target: AuthenticationPhone

trans-unit.source: OR
trans-unit.target: OR

trans-unit.source: MobilePhone
trans-unit.target: MobilePhone

trans-unit.source: (Authentication Phone is used if there is data present, otherwise this falls back to the mobile phone field).
trans-unit.target: (Authentication Phone is used if there is data present, otherwise this falls back to the mobile phone field).

trans-unit.source: e.g. Set-MsolUser -UserPrincipalName JWarner@contoso.com -MobilePhone "+1 1234567890x1234"
trans-unit.target: e.g. Set-MsolUser -UserPrincipalName JWarner@contoso.com -MobilePhone "+1 1234567890x1234"

trans-unit.source: Used in:
trans-unit.target: Used in:

trans-unit.source: Password Reset Portal
trans-unit.target: Password Reset Portal

trans-unit.source: Registration Portal
trans-unit.target: Registration Portal

trans-unit.source: Settable from:
trans-unit.target: Settable from:

trans-unit.source: AuthenticationPhone is settable from the password reset registration portal or MFA registration portal.
trans-unit.target: AuthenticationPhone is settable from the password reset registration portal or MFA registration portal.

trans-unit.source: MobilePhone is settable from PowerShell, DirSync, Azure Management Portal, and the Office Admin Portal
trans-unit.target: MobilePhone is settable from PowerShell, DirSync, Azure Management Portal, and the Office Admin Portal

trans-unit.source: +ccc xxxyyyzzzz (e.g. +1 1234567890)
trans-unit.target: +ccc xxxyyyzzzz (e.g. +1 1234567890)

trans-unit.source: Alternate Email
trans-unit.target: Alternate Email

trans-unit.source: AuthenticationEmail
trans-unit.target: AuthenticationEmail

trans-unit.source: OR
trans-unit.target: OR

trans-unit.source: AlternateEmailAddresses[0]
trans-unit.target: AlternateEmailAddresses[0]

trans-unit.source: (Authentication Email is used if there is data present, otherwise this falls back to the Alternate Email field).
trans-unit.target: (Authentication Email is used if there is data present, otherwise this falls back to the Alternate Email field).

trans-unit.source: Note: the alternate email field is specified as an array of strings in the directory.
trans-unit.target: Note: the alternate email field is specified as an array of strings in the directory.

trans-unit.source: We use the first entry in this array.
trans-unit.target: We use the first entry in this array.

trans-unit.source: e.g. Set-MsolUser -UserPrincipalName JWarner@contoso.com -AlternateEmailAddresses "email@live.com"
trans-unit.target: e.g. Set-MsolUser -UserPrincipalName JWarner@contoso.com -AlternateEmailAddresses "email@live.com"

trans-unit.source: Used in:
trans-unit.target: Used in:

trans-unit.source: Password Reset Portal
trans-unit.target: Password Reset Portal

trans-unit.source: Registration Portal
trans-unit.target: Registration Portal

trans-unit.source: Settable from:
trans-unit.target: Settable from:

trans-unit.source: AuthenticationEmail is settable from the password reset registration portal or MFA registration portal.
trans-unit.target: AuthenticationEmail is settable from the password reset registration portal or MFA registration portal.

trans-unit.source: AlternateEmail is settable from PowerShell, the Azure Management Portal, and the Office Admin Portal
trans-unit.target: AlternateEmail is settable from PowerShell, the Azure Management Portal, and the Office Admin Portal

trans-unit.source: user@domain.com or 甲斐@黒川.日本
trans-unit.target: user@domain.com or 甲斐@黒川.日本

trans-unit.source: Security Questions and Answers
trans-unit.target: Security Questions and Answers

trans-unit.source: Not available to modify directly in the directory.
trans-unit.target: Not available to modify directly in the directory.

trans-unit.source: Used in:
trans-unit.target: Used in:

trans-unit.source: Password Reset Portal
trans-unit.target: Password Reset Portal

trans-unit.source: Registration Portal
trans-unit.target: Registration Portal

trans-unit.source: Settable from:
trans-unit.target: Settable from:

trans-unit.source: The only way to set security questions is through the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: The only way to set security questions is through the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: The only way to set answers to security questions for a given user is through the Registration Portal.
trans-unit.target: The only way to set answers to security questions for a given user is through the Registration Portal.

trans-unit.source: Security questions have a max of 200 characters and a min of 3 characters
trans-unit.target: Security questions have a max of 200 characters and a min of 3 characters

trans-unit.source: Answers have a max of 40 characters and a min of 3 characters
trans-unit.target: Answers have a max of 40 characters and a min of 3 characters
